<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<BR>
DECEMBER 31, 2004, 2003 AND 2002</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;America West Holdings Corporation (&#147;Holdings&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;) is a holding company that
owns all of the stock of America West Airlines, Inc. (&#147;AWA&#148; or the &#147;Airline&#148;). AWA accounted for
most of the Company&#146;s revenues and expenses in 2004. Based on 2004 operating revenues and
available seat miles (&#147;ASMs&#148;), AWA is the eighth largest passenger airline in the United States
with the lowest cost structure of the eight major hub-and-spoke airlines. At the end of 2004, AWA
operated a fleet of 138 aircraft with an average fleet age of 10.7&nbsp;years and served 63 destinations
in North America, including eight in Mexico, three in Canada and one in Costa Rica. Through
regional alliance and code share arrangements with other airlines, AWA served an additional 51
destinations in North America and the Middle East as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. In 2004, AWA flew
approximately 21.1&nbsp;million passengers and generated revenues of approximately $2.3&nbsp;billion. Prior
to 2004, Holdings owned the outstanding stock of The Leisure Company (&#147;TLC&#148;), which sells
individual and group travel packages, including air transportation of AWA and Hawaiian Airlines,
hotel accommodations, car rentals, cruise packages and other travel products, directly to consumers
as well as through retail travel agencies in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Costa Rica. As
of January&nbsp;1, 2004, TLC has been merged into AWA and continues to operate as the America West
Vacations division of AWA.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(a)&nbsp;Basis of Presentation</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Holdings and its wholly owned
subsidiary AWA, which includes its wholly owned subsidiary Flight Training Center Hangar Plan. All
significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. Certain
reclassifications have been made to the prior years&#146; consolidated financial statements to conform
to the current year&#146;s presentation.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(b)&nbsp;Cash, Cash Equivalents and Short-term Investments</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash equivalents consist of all highly liquid debt instruments purchased with original
maturities of three months or less. Short-term investments consist of cash invested in certain
debt securities with original maturities greater than 90&nbsp;days and less than one year. The debt
securities are classified as held to maturity and are carried at amortized cost that approximates
fair value.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reclassified investments in auction rate securities previously classified as cash
equivalents to short-term investments on the accompanying consolidated balance sheets. Investments
reclassified in 2004 and 2003 were $58.4&nbsp;million and $249.7&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(c)&nbsp;Expendable Spare Parts and Supplies</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight equipment expendable spare parts and supplies are valued at average cost. An allowance
for obsolescence is provided, over the estimated useful life of the related aircraft and engines,
for spare parts expected to be on hand at the date the aircraft are retired from service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(d)&nbsp;Property and Equipment</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property and equipment are recorded at cost. Interest capitalized on advance payments for
aircraft acquisitions and on expenditures for aircraft improvements are part of these costs.
Interest capitalized for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, was $2.2&nbsp;million, $1.6
million and $3.0&nbsp;million, respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and amortized to
residual values over the estimated useful lives or the lease term, whichever is less, using the
straight-line method.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The estimated useful lives for the Company&#146;s ground property and equipment range from three to
12&nbsp;years for owned property and equipment and up to 30&nbsp;years for the flight training facility. The
estimated useful lives of the Company&#146;s owned aircraft, jet engines, flight equipment and rotable
parts range from five to 25&nbsp;years. Leasehold improvements relating to flight equipment and other
property on operating leases are amortized over the life of the lease or the life of the asset,
whichever is shorter.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">47
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company records impairment losses on long-lived assets used in operations when events and
circumstances indicate that the assets might be impaired as defined by Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&nbsp;144, <I>&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
Assets.&#148; </I>Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying
amount of an asset to undiscounted future net cash flows expected to be generated by the asset. If
such assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment to be recognized is measured by the
amount by which the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets. Assets to
be disposed of are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or fair value less cost to sell.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(e)&nbsp;Restricted Cash</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted cash includes cash deposits securing certain letters of credit and surety bonds and
cash deposits held by institutions that process credit card sales transactions. Current restricted
cash includes amounts set aside in an irrevocable trust for the redemption of the 10 <FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>% senior
unsecured notes that was subsequently paid on January&nbsp;26, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(f)&nbsp;Aircraft Maintenance and Repairs</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Routine maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred. The cost of major
scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhauls are capitalized and amortized over the
periods benefited and are included in aircraft maintenance materials and repairs expense.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2004, the Company revised the estimated useful life for certain
aircraft and related spare parts inventory as a result of changes in AWA&#146;s fleet plan and for
capitalized maintenance on certain of its engines as a result of changes in aircraft utilization.
The net impact of this change in estimate decreased the net loss for 2004 by approximately $18.4
million or $0.51 per basic and diluted share.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An accrual for the estimated cost of scheduled airframe and engine overhauls required to be
performed on leased aircraft prior to their return to the lessors has also been recorded. These
estimates are based on historical costs and our assumptions regarding the renewal of aircraft
leases.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(g)&nbsp;Derivative Instruments</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA&#146;s fuel hedging contracts do not qualify as cash flow hedges under Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;133, <I>&#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&#148; </I>(&#147;SFAS
No.&nbsp;133&#148;). See Note 2, <I>&#147;Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts.&#148; </I>Accordingly, the derivative
hedging instruments are recorded as an asset or liability on the balance sheet at fair value and
the changes in the fair values are recorded in <I>&#147;Gain (Loss) on Derivative Instruments, Net</I>&#148; in the
accompanying consolidated statements of operations. See Note 12, <I>&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expenses) &#151;
Other, Net.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(h)&nbsp;Frequent Flyer Awards</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company maintains a frequent travel award program known as &#147;FlightFund&#148; that provides a
variety of awards to program members based on accumulated mileage. The estimated cost of providing
the free travel, using the incremental cost method as adjusted for estimated redemption rates, is
recognized as a liability and charged to operations as program members accumulate mileage.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company also sells mileage credits to companies participating in its FlightFund program,
such as hotels, car rental agencies and credit card companies. Transportation-related revenue from
the sale of mileage credits is deferred and recognized when transportation is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(i)&nbsp;Deferred Credits-Operating Leases</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rents for operating leases were adjusted to fair market value when the Company emerged from
bankruptcy in 1994. The net present value of the difference between the stated lease rates and the
fair market rates has been recorded as a deferred credit in the accompanying consolidated balance
sheets. The deferred credit will be increased through charges to interest expense and decreased on
a straight-line basis as a reduction in rent expense over the applicable lease periods. At
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the unamortized balance of the deferred credit was $38.3&nbsp;million and
$44.6&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">48
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380&nbsp;million government loan
guarantee. This loan triggered aircraft rent concessions negotiated with approximately 20 aircraft
lessors. Approximately $18.1&nbsp;million of aircraft rent, which was accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2001,
was waived by the aircraft lessors. This amount has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheet and will be amortized over the remaining lives of the
applicable leases as a reduction in rent expense. At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the unamortized
balance of the deferred credit was approximately $4.2&nbsp;million and $7.8&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(j)&nbsp;Passenger Revenue</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided. Ticket sales for
transportation that has not yet been provided are recorded as air traffic liability. Passenger
traffic commissions and related fees are expensed when the related revenue is recognized. Due to
complex pricing structures, refund and exchange policies, and interline agreements with other
airlines, certain amounts are recognized in revenue using estimates regarding both the timing of
the revenue recognition and the amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates are generally
based on the statistical analysis of the Company&#146;s historical data. Any adjustments resulting from
periodic evaluations of the estimated air traffic liability are included in results of operations
during the period in which the evaluations are completed.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(k)&nbsp;Reorganization
Value in Excess of Amounts Applicable to Identifiable Assets
(&#147;ERV&#148;)</I></B>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;)
issued SFAS No.&nbsp;412, <I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible
Assets.&#148;</I> SFAS No.&nbsp;142 primarily addresses the
accounting for goodwill and intangible assets subsequent to their
acquisition. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 does not permit the amortization of
goodwill as required by Accounting Principles Board (&#147;APB&#148;)
Opinion No.&nbsp;17, <I>&#147;Intangible Assets.&#148;</I> Rather,
goodwill is subject to a periodic impairment test, using a two-step
process. The first step is to identify a potential impairment. The
second step of the goodwill impairment test measures the amount of
the Impairment loss, using a fair value-based approach. Under SFAS
No.&nbsp;142, ERV is reported as goodwill and accounted for in the
same manner as goodwill. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 was affective for fiscal
years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2001. Upon adoption of this
statement on January&nbsp;1, 2002, the Company recorded an impairment
loss of $208.2&nbsp;million, which was supported by an independent
valuation of the Company. The impairment loss was recorded as the
cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(l)&nbsp;Advertising Costs</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company expenses the costs of advertising as incurred. Advertising expense for the years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 was $8.3&nbsp;million, $9.0&nbsp;million and $10.6&nbsp;million,
respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(m)&nbsp;Income Taxes</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method. Deferred tax assets and
liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the
financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax
bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards. A valuation allowance is established, if
necessary, for the amount of any tax benefits that, based on available evidence, are not expected
to be realized.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(n)&nbsp;Stock Options</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had two stock-based employee compensation plans, which are
described more fully in Note 9, <I>&#147;Stock Options and Awards.&#148; </I>The Company accounts for its stock
option plans in accordance with the provisions of APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25, <I>&#147;Accounting for Stock Issued
to Employees,&#148; </I>and related interpretations. As such, compensation expense would be recorded on the
date of grant only if the current market price of the underlying stock exceeded the exercise price.
Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for stock options in the consolidated
financial statements. Had the Company determined compensation cost based on the fair value at the
grant date for its stock options under SFAS No.&nbsp;123, <I>&#147;Accounting for Share-Based Payment,&#148; </I>the
Company&#146;s net income (loss)&nbsp;and earnings (loss)&nbsp;per share would have been reduced to the pro forma
amounts indicated below:

<DIV align="center">

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(o)&nbsp;New Accounting Standards</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November&nbsp;2004, the Emerging Issues Task Force (&#147;EITF&#148;) of the FASB reached a consensus on
EITF 04-08, <I>&#147;The Effect of Contingently Convertible Instruments on Diluted Earnings per Share,&#148;</I>
which requires that issuers of convertible securities with contingent conversion features use the
&#147;if-converted&#148; method to calculate reported earnings per share (&#147;EPS&#148;) irrespective of the
contingent conversion trigger being met. As approved by the FASB, this change is effective for
years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2004. The Company applied this methodology in the accompanying
consolidated statement of operations. The impact of using the &#147;if-converted&#148; method for the
Company&#146;s 7.25% Notes is antidilutive for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2002. For the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, the inclusion of the 7.25% Notes reduced diluted EPS by $0.03 from $1.29
to $1.26.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Revised Statement No.&nbsp;123, <I>&#147;Accounting for Share-Based
Payment&#148; </I>(&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;123R&#148;). This statement requires the Company to recognize the grant-date fair
value of stock options in the Statement of Operations. In addition, the Company will be required
to calculate this compensation using the fair-value based method, versus the intrinsic value method
previously allowed under SFAS No.&nbsp;123. This revision is effective for periods beginning after June
15, 2005. Accordingly, the Company will adopt this revised SFAS effective July&nbsp;1, 2005. The
Company is currently evaluating how it will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;123R and has not determined the method
it will use to value granted stock options. The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R is expected to have a
material effect on the Company&#146;s results of operations. See Note 1, <I>&#147;Summary of Significant
Accounting Policies&#148; </I>(m) <I>&#147;Stock Options&#148; </I>for the Company&#146;s disclosure of the impact of the
compensation cost associated with stock options under SFAS No.&nbsp;123.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(p)&nbsp;Use of Estimates</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management of the Company has made certain estimates and assumptions relating to the reporting
of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities to prepare these
consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in
the United States. Actual results could differ from those estimates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(q)&nbsp;Reclassifications</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reclassified amounts related to settled fuel hedge transactions and mark-to-market
adjustments on open hedge instruments from <I>&#147;Aircraft Fuel&#148; </I>expense to <I>&#147;Gain (Loss) on Derivative
Instruments, Net&#148; </I>in the accompanying consolidated statement of operations. In fiscal years 2004
and 2003, such amounts reduced fuel expense while in fiscal years 2002 and 2001, such amounts
increased fuel expense, as originally classified. The amounts reclassified are as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>2. Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Derivative Instruments</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February 2005, management undertook a review of the Company&#146;s
accounting for its fuel hedging transactions. As a result of this
review, management concluded that the Company&#146;s fuel hedging
transactions did not qualify for hedge accounting under U.S.
generally accepted accounting principles. Accordingly, management
concluded that the financial statements for prior periods required
restatement to reflect the fair value of fuel hedging contracts in
the balance sheets and statements of stockholders equity and
comprehensive income of Holdings and AWA. Specifically,
(i)&nbsp;Holdings has restated its balance sheet and statement of
stockholders&#146; equity and comprehensive income as of and for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, and (ii)&nbsp;AWA has restated its
balance sheet and statement of stockholder&#146;s equity and
comprehensive income as of and for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2003, and (iii)&nbsp;Holdings and AWA have restated their 2004 and
2003 interim financial results to correct the aforementioned
accounting errors. The unaudited interim results as originally
reported and as restated are presented in Note&nbsp;16,
&#147;<I>Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited)</I>.&#148; The Company
restated its 2003 consolidated balance sheet to reduce the carrying
value of its derivative instruments asset by $12.5&nbsp;million,
which served to record the asset at fair value of open contracts as
of December&nbsp;31, 2003. The restatement also eliminated
$12.5&nbsp;million in accumulated other comprehensive income,
$2.0&nbsp;million of which was previously recorded in the 2003
beginning balance of accumulated other comprehensive income. The
restated amount of other assets is $112&nbsp;million in the
accompanying 2003 consolidated balance sheet. The restatement
eliminates the balance in accumulated other comprehensive income in
the accompanying 2003 consolidated balance sheet and consolidated
statement of stockholders&#146; equity and comprehensive income.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">50

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the Company had long-term investments in debt securities of $30.0&nbsp;million
and $40.7&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. Long-term investments consist of
cash invested in certain debt securities with maturities greater than one year. The debt
securities are classified as held to maturity and are carried at amortized cost that approximates
fair value.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>4. Financial Instruments and Risk Management</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(a)&nbsp;Fair Value of Financial Instruments</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash Equivalents, Short-term Investments and Receivables</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amount approximates fair value because of the short-term nature of these
instruments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Investments in Equity Securities</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2000, Holdings completed the sale of a majority interest in The Leisure Company,
(&#147;TLC&#148;), currently operating as a division in AWA as America West Vacations, retail operations,
National Leisure Group and The Vacation Store, to Softbank Capital Partners and General Catalyst
LLC. TLC received $52&nbsp;million in cash and retained a 12% passive ownership interest in the
restructured venture. In response to additional capital calls, TLC invested an additional $1.2
million in National Leisure Group during 2001. The investment was carried on the Company&#146;s
consolidated balance sheet at cost, which approximated $7.7&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002. In the
fourth quarter of 2003, Holdings completed the sale of its 12% interest in National Leisure Group
to PAR Capital. PAR Capital owned $10.45&nbsp;million face value of
the Company&#146;s 10 3/4% senior
unsecured notes. PAR Capital purchased the Company&#146;s investment in National Leisure Group in
exchange for the $10.45&nbsp;million face value of the 10 3/4% notes plus $0.3&nbsp;million in cash. This
resulted in a $3.3&nbsp;million nonoperating gain. See Note 12, <I>&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expenses) &#150;
Other, Net.&#148;</I>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">51
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Long-term Debt</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the fair value of long-term debt was approximately $721.5
million and $845.6&nbsp;million, respectively. The Company&#146;s variable rate long-term debt with a
carrying value of $545.7&nbsp;million and $555.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively,
approximates fair value because these borrowings have variable interest rate terms that approximate
market interest rates for similar debt instruments. The fair values of the Company&#146;s other
long-term debt are determined based on quoted market prices if available or market prices for
comparable debt instruments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(b)&nbsp;Fuel Price Risk Management</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under its fuel hedging program, the Company may enter into certain hedging transactions with
approved counterparties for a period generally not exceeding 12&nbsp;months. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004,
the Company had entered into costless collar and basis swap transactions hedging approximately 42%
of its projected 2005 fuel requirements. The fair value of the Company&#146;s financial derivative
instruments was a net asset of approximately $0.2&nbsp;million and $2.7&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004
and 2003, respectively. See Note 2, <I>&#147;Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is exposed to credit risks in the event any counterparty fails to meet its
obligations. The Company does not anticipate such non-performance as counterparties are selected
based on credit ratings, exposure to any one counterparty is limited based on formal guidelines and
the relative market positions with such counterparties are closely monitored.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(c)&nbsp;Concentration of Credit Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company does not believe it is subject to any significant concentration of credit risk.
Most of the Company&#146;s receivables result from tickets sold to individual passengers through the use
of major credit cards or from tickets sold by other airlines and used by passengers on AWA. These
receivables are short-term, generally being settled shortly after the sale.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>5.&nbsp;Long-Term Debt</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Long-term debt at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 consists of the following:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>2004</B></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>2003</B></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On September&nbsp;10, 2004, AWA entered into a term loan financing with GECC
providing for loans in an aggregate amount of $110.6&nbsp;million. AWA used
approximately $77.0&nbsp;million of the proceeds from this financing to repay in full
its term loan with Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd. and certain other lenders and to
pay certain costs associated with this transaction. AWA used the remaining
proceeds for general corporate purposes. The new term loan financing consists of
two secured term loan facilities: a $75.6&nbsp;million term loan facility secured
primarily by spare parts, rotables and appliances (the &#147;Spare Parts Facility&#148;);
and a $35.0&nbsp;million term loan facility secured primarily by aircraft engines and
parts installed in such engines (the &#147;Engine Facility&#148;).</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The facilities are cross-collateralized on a subordinated basis and the collateral
securing the facilities also secures on a subordinated basis certain of AWA&#146;s other
existing debt and lease obligations to GECC and its affiliates.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The loans under the Spare Parts Facility are payable in full at maturity on
September&nbsp;10, 2010. The loans under the Engine Facility are payable in equal
quarterly installments of $1.3&nbsp;million beginning on March&nbsp;10, 2006 through June&nbsp;10,
2010 with the remaining loan amount of $11.8&nbsp;million payable at maturity on
September&nbsp;10, 2010. The loans under each facility may be prepaid in an amount not
less than $5&nbsp;million at any time after the 30th monthly anniversary of the funding
date under such facility. If AWA fails to maintain a certain ratio of rotables to
loans under the Spare Parts Facility, it may be required to pledge additional
rotables or cash as collateral, provide a letter of credit or prepay some or all of
the loans under the Spare Parts Facility. In addition, the loans under the Engine
Facility are subject to mandatory prepayment upon the occurrence of certain events
of loss applicable to, or certain dispositions of, aircraft engines securing the
facility.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Principal amounts outstanding under the loans bear interest at a rate per annum
based on three-month LIBOR plus a margin. Both facilities contain customary events
of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults, breach of covenants,
bankruptcy and insolvency defaults and judgment defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On December&nbsp;27, 2004, AWA raised additional capital by financing its Phoenix
maintenance facility and flight training center. The flight training center was
previously unencumbered, and the maintenance facility became unencumbered earlier
this year when AWA refinanced its term loan. Using its leasehold interest these
two facilities as collateral, AWA, through a wholly owned subsidiary named FTCHP
LLC, raised $30.8&nbsp;million through the issuance of a senior secured discount notes.
The notes were issued by FTCHP at a discount pursuant to the terms of a senior
secured term loan agreement among the Company, FTCHP, Heritage Bank, SSB, as
administrative agent, Citibank, N.A., as the initial lender, and the other lenders
from time to time party thereto. Citibank, N.A. subsequently assigned all of its
interests in the notes to third party lenders.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>AWA has fully and unconditionally guaranteed the payment and performance of FTCHP&#146;s
obligations under the notes and the loan agreement. The notes require aggregate
principal payments of $36&nbsp;million with principal payments of $1.5&nbsp;million due on
each of the first two anniversary dates and the remaining principal amount due on
the fifth anniversary date. The notes may be prepaid in full at any time (subject
to customary LIBOR breakage costs) and in partial amounts of $1.5&nbsp;million on the
third and fourth anniversary dates. The unpaid principal amount of the notes bears
interest based on LIBOR plus a margin subject to adjustment based on a loan to
collateral value ratio.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The loan agreement contains customary covenants applicable to loans of this type,
including obligations relating to the preservation of the collateral and
restrictions on the activities of FTCHP. In addition, the loan agreement contains
events of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults to other debt of
FTCHP, if any, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and insolvency defaults and judgment
defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In connection with this financing, AWA sold all of its leasehold interests in the
maintenance facility and flight training center to FTCHP and entered into subleases
for the facilities with FTCHP at lease rates expected to approximate the interest
payments due under the notes. In addition, AWA agreed to make future capital
contributions to FTCHP in amounts sufficient to cover principal payments and other
amounts owing pursuant to the notes and the loan agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The proceeds from this financing, together with $10.5&nbsp;million from operating cash
flow, were irrevocably deposited with the trustee for AWA&#146;s 10 3/4% senior
unsecured notes due 2005 and subsequently redeemed on January&nbsp;26, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(c)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In January&nbsp;2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a $380&nbsp;million
federal loan guarantee provided by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board (the
&#147;ATSB&#148;). Certain third-party counter-guarantors have fully and unconditionally
guaranteed the payment of an aggregate of $45&nbsp;million of the outstanding principal
amount under the government guaranteed loan plus accrued and unpaid interest
thereon. In addition, Holdings has fully and unconditionally guaranteed the
payment of all principal, premium, interest and other</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">53
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">



</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"></TD>
    <TD> obligations outstanding under the government guaranteed loan and has pledged the
stock of AWA to secure its obligations under such guarantee. Principal amounts
under this loan become due in ten installments of $42.9&nbsp;million on each March&nbsp;31
and September&nbsp;30, commencing on March&nbsp;31, 2004 and ending on September&nbsp;30, 2008.
Principal amounts outstanding under the government guaranteed loan bear interest at
a rate per annum equal to LIBOR plus 40 basis points.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Subject to certain exceptions, AWA is required to prepay the government guaranteed
loan with:</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the net proceeds of all issuances of debt or equity by either Holdings or AWA after January&nbsp;2002;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>proceeds from asset sales in excess of $20&nbsp;million in any fiscal year; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>insurance proceeds in excess of $2&nbsp;million to the extent such proceeds
are not used to restore or replace the assets from which such proceeds are
derived.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In addition, AWA is required to prepay the government guaranteed loan upon a change
in control and we may be required to prepay portions of the loan if our employee
compensation costs exceed a certain threshold. AWA may, at its option, prepay the
government guaranteed loan without premium or penalty, subject to reimbursement of
the lenders&#146; breakage costs in the case of prepayment of LIBOR loans.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The government guaranteed loan requires that AWA maintain a minimum cash balance of
$100&nbsp;million. In addition, the government loan contains customary affirmative
covenants and the following negative covenants: restrictions on liens, investments,
restricted payments, fundamental changes, asset sales and acquisitions, the
creation of new subsidiaries, sale and leasebacks, transactions with affiliates,
the conduct of business, mergers or consolidations, issuances and dispositions of
capital stock of subsidiaries, and amendments to other indebtedness. The
government guaranteed loan contains customary events of default, including payment
defaults, cross-defaults, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and insolvency defaults
and judgment defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(d)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In August&nbsp;1995, AWA issued $75.0&nbsp;million principal
amount of 10 3/4% senior
unsecured notes due 2005 of which $39.5&nbsp;million remained outstanding at December
31, 2004. Interest on the 10 3/4% senior unsecured notes is payable semiannually in
arrears on March 1 and September 1 of each year. On December&nbsp;27, 2004, AWA called
for the redemption on January&nbsp;26, 2005 of all of the senior unsecured notes at a
redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid
interest through the redemption date. In addition, AWA irrevocably deposited the
$30.8&nbsp;million raised through the maintenance facility and flight training center
financing, together with an additional $10.5&nbsp;million from its operating cash flow,
with the trustee for the senior unsecured notes. The senior notes were
subsequently redeemed on January&nbsp;26, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(e)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In connection with the closing of the government guaranteed loan and the
related transactions, Holdings issued $104.5&nbsp;million of 7.5% convertible senior
notes due 2009, of which approximately $112.3&nbsp;million remained outstanding at
December&nbsp;31, 2004 (including $21.6&nbsp;million of interest paid through December&nbsp;31,
2004 as a deemed loan added to the initial principal thereof). Beginning January
18, 2005, these notes are convertible into shares of class B common stock, at the
option of the holders, at an initial conversion price of $12.00 per share or a
conversion ratio of approximately 83.333 shares per $1,000 principal amount of such
notes, subject to standard anti-dilution adjustments. Interest on the 7.5%
convertible senior notes is payable semiannually in arrears on June 1 and December
1 of each year. At Holdings&#146; option, the first six interest payments were payable
in the form of a deemed loan added to the principal amount of these notes. The
7.5% convertible senior notes will mature on January&nbsp;18, 2009 unless earlier
converted or redeemed. The payment of principal, premium and interest on the 7.5%
convertible senior notes is fully and unconditionally guaranteed by AWA.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Holdings may redeem some or all of the 7.5% convertible senior notes at any time
before January&nbsp;18, 2005, at a redemption price equal to $1,000 per note to be
redeemed if (A)&nbsp;the closing price of the class B common stock has exceeded 120% of
the conversion price then in effect for at least 20 trading days within a period of
30 consecutive trading days ending on the trading day before the date of the
mailing of the redemption notice, and (B)&nbsp;a shelf registration statement covering
resales of the notes and the class B common stock issuable upon conversion thereof
is effective and available for use and is expected to remain effective and
available for use for the 30&nbsp;days following the redemption date, unless
registration is no longer required. Holdings may redeem the 7.5% convertible
senior notes, in whole or in part, on or after January&nbsp;18, 2005 at the following
redemption prices (expressed as percentages of the principal amount thereof), if
redeemed during the twelve-month period commencing on January&nbsp;18 of the years set
forth below, plus, in each case, accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the date
of redemption:</TD>

in any fiscal quarter commencing after September&nbsp;30, 2003, if, as of the last day
of the preceding fiscal quarter, the closing sale price of the class B common stock
for at least 20 trading days in a period of 30 consecutive trading days ending on
the last trading day of such preceding fiscal quarter is more than 110% of the
accreted exchange price per share of Class&nbsp;B common stock on the last day of such
preceding fiscal quarter. If the foregoing condition is satisfied, then the notes
will be exchangeable at any time at the option of the holder through maturity. The
accreted exchange price per share as of any day will equal the issue price of a
note plus accrued original issue discount to that day divided by 32.038, subject to
any adjustments to the exchange rate through that day.</TD>

<TR>

    <TD>On or before July&nbsp;30, 2018, a holder also may exchange its notes for shares of the
Class&nbsp;B common stock at any time after a 10 consecutive trading-day period in which
the average of the trading prices for the notes for that 10 trading-day period was
less than 103% of the average exchange value for the notes during that period.
Exchange value is equal to the product of the closing sale price for the shares of
Class&nbsp;B common stock on a given day multiplied by the then current exchange rate,
which is the number of shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock for which each note is then
exchangeable.</TD>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain of the Company&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain minimum cash balance
requirements and other covenants with which Holdings and AWA are in compliance. Certain of these
covenants restrict the Company&#146;s ability to pay cash dividends on its common stock and make certain
other restricted payments (as specified therein). Finally, AWA&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain
cross-default provisions, which may be triggered by defaults by AWA under other agreements relating
to indebtedness.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>6. Commitments and Contingencies</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(a)&nbsp;Leases</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had 136 aircraft under operating leases, including four
aircraft that will be delivered in 2005, with remaining terms ranging from five months to
approximately 19&nbsp;years. In January&nbsp;2002, in connection with the government guaranteed loan, AWA
restructured its aircraft lease commitments. Under the restructured lease agreements, annual rent
payments have been reduced for each of the next five years. Certain of these leases contain put
options pursuant to which the lessors could require AWA to renew the leases for periods ranging
from eight months to approximately nine years or call options pursuant to which the lessors could
require AWA to return the aircraft to the lessors upon receipt of six to nine months written
notice. The Company also has options to purchase certain of the aircraft at fair market values at
the end of the lease terms. Certain of the agreements require security deposits, minimum return
provisions and supplemental rent payments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since AWA&#146;s restructuring in 1994, AWA has set up 19 pass through trusts, which have issued
over $1.4&nbsp;billion of pass through trust certificates (also known as &#147;Enhanced Equipment Trust
Certificates&#148; or &#147;EETC&#148;) covering the financing of 54 aircraft. These trusts are off-balance sheet
entities, the primary purpose of which is to finance the acquisition of aircraft. Rather than
finance each aircraft separately when such aircraft is purchased or delivered, these trusts allow
the Company to raise the financing for several aircraft at one time and place such funds in escrow
pending the purchase or delivery of the relevant aircraft. The trusts are also structured to
provide for certain credit enhancements, such as liquidity facilities to cover certain interest
payments, that reduce the risks to the purchasers of the trust certificates and, as a result,
reduce the cost of aircraft financings to AWA.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be delivered within a specific period of
time. At the time of each covered aircraft financing, the relevant trust used the funds in escrow
to purchase equipment notes relating to the financed aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at
AWA&#146;s election, either by AWA in connection with a mortgage financing of the aircraft or by a
separate owner trust in connection with a leveraged lease financing of the aircraft. In the case
of a leveraged lease financing, the owner trust then leased the aircraft to AWA. In both cases,
the equipment notes are secured by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through trust
certificates are not direct obligations of, nor guaranteed by, Holdings or AWA. However, in the
case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes issued to the trusts are direct obligations of AWA
and in the case of leveraged lease financings, the leases are direct obligations of AWA. In
addition, neither Holdings nor AWA guarantee or participate in any way in the residual value of the
leased aircraft. All aircraft financed by these trusts are currently structured as leveraged lease
financings, which are not reflected as debt on the balance sheets of either AWA or Holdings. The
Company does not provide residual value guarantees under these lease arrangements. Each lease
contains a purchase option that allows the Company to purchase the aircraft at a fixed price, which
at the inception of the lease approximated the aircraft&#146;s expected fair market value at the option
date, near the end of the lease term. These leasing entities meet the criteria for variable
interest entities. However, they do not meet the consolidation criteria under FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46, <I>&#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; </I>because the Company is not the primary
beneficiary under these arrangements.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">56
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the rent restructuring associated with the government guaranteed loan, one
aircraft lease was amended to include a bargain purchase option. As a result, this lease has been
classified as a capital lease in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;13, <I>&#147;Accounting for Leases,&#148; </I>as amended,
with an asset value of $14.8&nbsp;million which includes accumulated amortization of $2.1&nbsp;million and
corresponding lease obligation of $8.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2004, one aircraft lessor exercised its put rights under the aircraft lease
agreement to extend the lease for one Boeing 737-300 aircraft for an additional 33&nbsp;months.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company also leases certain terminal space, ground facilities and computer and other
equipment under noncancelable operating leases.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rent expense (excluding landing fees) was approximately $421.1&nbsp;million, $406.8&nbsp;million
and $409.4&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Collectively, the operating lease agreements require security deposits with lessors of $24.0
million, which have been classified as <I>&#147;Other Assets, Net&#148; </I>in the accompanying consolidated balance
sheets, and bank letters of credit of $13.8&nbsp;million. The letters of credit are collateralized by
$13.9&nbsp;million of restricted cash.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(b)&nbsp;Revenue Bonds</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;1999, Series&nbsp;1999 special facility revenue bonds (&#147;new bonds&#148;) were issued by a
municipality to fund the retirement of the Series&nbsp;1994A bonds (&#147;old bonds&#148;) and the construction of
a new concourse with 14 gates at Terminal 4 in Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport in support
of AWA&#146;s strategic growth plan. The new bonds are due June&nbsp;2019 with interest accruing at 6.25%
per annum payable semiannually on June 1 and December&nbsp;1, commencing on December&nbsp;1, 1999. The new
bonds are subject to optional redemption prior to the maturity date on or after June&nbsp;1, 2009 in
whole or in part, on any interest payment date at the following redemption prices: 101% on June 1
or December&nbsp;1, 2009; 100.5% on June 1 or December&nbsp;1, 2010; and 100% on June&nbsp;1, 2011 and thereafter.
In accordance with EITF Issue No.&nbsp;97-10, <I>&#147;The Effect of Lessee Involvement in Asset Construction,&#148;</I>
the Company accounts for this as an operating lease.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with these bonds, AWA entered into an Amended and Restated Airport Use
Agreement, pursuant to which AWA agreed to make sufficient payments to the Industrial Development
Authority (&#147;IDA&#148;) to cover the principal and interest of the bonds and to indemnify the IDA for any
claims arising out of the issuance and sale of the bonds and the use and occupancy of the
concourses financed by these bonds and the old bonds. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the outstanding
principal amount of the bonds was $21.8&nbsp;million. The Company estimates its remaining payments to
cover the principal and interest of these bonds will be approximately $43.6&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the Company is also the lessee under certain long-term leases at various
airports. At certain of these airports, municipalities have issued revenue bonds to improve
airport facilities that are leased by the Company and accounted for as operating leases. The
Company does not guarantee the underlying debt related to these operating leases.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">57
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(c)&nbsp;Aircraft Acquisitions</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2004, AWA amended its aircraft purchase contract with AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of
Airbus Industrie or &#147;AVSA,&#148; to acquire 22 Airbus A320 family aircraft (thirteen A320s and nine
A319s), all powered by V2500 engines from International Aero Engines. Of the 22 aircraft, it is
anticipated that 18 will be purchased directly from the manufacturer and four have been leased
under noncancelable leases from various lessors for aircraft to be delivered in 2005. In the
context of this incremental order, AWA also secured extensive flexibility from Airbus with respect
to its existing A318 order, allowing AWA to better react to market conditions by enabling it to
amend its 15 A318 delivery positions to A319s and A320s, if it so desires, or to take no additional
aircraft under certain conditions.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has an agreement with International Aero Engines or &#147;IAE,&#148; which provides for the
purchase by the Company of seven new V2500-A5 spare engines scheduled for delivery through 2007 for
use on certain of the Airbus A320 fleet. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, the seven engines have an estimated
gross cost of $39&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table reflects estimated net cash payments under the restructured aircraft
purchase agreement with AVSA and the IAE engine contract. Actual payments may vary due to
inflation factor adjustments and changes in the delivery schedule of the equipment.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(d)&nbsp;Sale-Leaseback Transactions</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the fourth quarter of 2004, the Company completed two separate aircraft sale-leaseback
transactions on one Airbus A320 aircraft and one Airbus A319 aircraft resulting in a combined loss
of $4.6&nbsp;million. This amount was recorded in <I>&#147;Other Operating Expenses.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2004, the Company completed a sale-leaseback transaction on one V2500-A5 engine
resulting in a gain of $2.9&nbsp;million which has been deferred and will be amortized over the lease
term of seven years.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2004, the Company completed a sale-leaseback transaction on one V2500-A5 engine
resulting in a gain of $0.8&nbsp;million which has been deferred and will be amortized over the lease
term of seven years.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002, AWA committed to the sale and
leaseback of eight aircraft. The sales and leaseback of six of these aircraft were completed in
2002 and resulted in losses of approximately $3.8&nbsp;million. The sale and leaseback of one aircraft
was completed in June&nbsp;2003 and resulted in a loss of approximately $0.6&nbsp;million. The sale and
leaseback of the final aircraft was completed in September&nbsp;2003 and resulted in a loss of
approximately $0.7&nbsp;million. The losses on the sale-leaseback transactions, which were subject to a
firm commitment in January&nbsp;2002, were accrued in the accompanying consolidated statements of
operations classified in <I>&#147;Special Charges&#148; </I>in the first quarter of 2002. See Note 11, <I>&#147;Special
Charges.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(e)&nbsp;Contingent Legal Obligations</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holdings and its subsidiaries are parties to various legal proceedings, including some
purporting to be class action suits, and some that demand large monetary damages or other relief,
which, if granted, would require significant expenditures. In certain cases where it is probable
that the outcome will result in monetary damages, the Company has reviewed available information
and determined that the best estimate of losses to be incurred related to these cases is $2
million, which has been accrued. For those cases where a loss is possible, or cases where a range
of loss is probable but no amount within the range is a better estimate than any other amount, the
estimated amount of additional exposure ranges from $0 to $25&nbsp;million. In these instances, no
accrual has been recorded.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">58
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(f)&nbsp;General Guarantees and Indemnifications</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is the lessee under many aircraft financing agreements (including leveraged lease
financings of aircraft under the pass through trusts) and real estate leases. It is common in such
transactions for the Company as the lessee to agree to indemnify the lessor and other related third
parties for the manufacture, design, ownership, financing, use, operation and maintenance of the
aircraft, and for tort liabilities that arise out of or relate to the Company&#146;s use or occupancy of
the leased asset. In some cases, this indemnity extends to related liabilities arising from the
negligence of the indemnified parties, but usually excludes any liabilities caused by their gross
negligence or willful misconduct. Additionally, in the case of real estate leases, the Company
typically indemnifies such parties for any environmental liability that arises out of or relates to
the Company&#146;s use of the leased premises. The Company expects that it would be covered by
insurance (subject to deductibles) for most tort liabilities and related indemnities described
above with respect to leased real estate and operated aircraft.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy reorganization in 1994 and the associated
implementation of fresh start reporting gave rise to significant items of expense for financial
reporting purposes that are not deductible for income tax purposes. In large measure, it is these
nondeductible (for income tax purposes) expenses that result in an effective tax expense (benefit)
rate for financial reporting purposes that differs from the current federal statutory income tax
rate of 35%.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense (benefit)&nbsp;differs from amounts computed at the federal statutory income tax

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company has available net operating loss carryforwards
(&#147;NOLs&#148;) and tax credit carryforwards for federal income tax purposes of approximately $451.4
million and $1.1&nbsp;million, respectively. The NOLs expire during the years 2007 through 2024 while
approximately $0.2&nbsp;million of the tax credit carryforwards will expire in 2005 and 2006. The
Company also had capital loss carryforwards for federal income tax purposes of approximately $1.4
million which expire in 2009. However, such carryforwards are not available to offset federal (and
in certain circumstances, state) alternative minimum taxable income. Further, as a result of a
statutory &#147;ownership change&#148; (as defined for purposes of Section&nbsp;382 of the Internal Revenue Code)
that occurred as a result of the Company&#146;s reorganization in 1994, the Company&#146;s ability to utilize
its NOLs and tax credit carryforwards may be restricted.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2003, Holdings filed its 2002 consolidated income tax return with the IRS, which
included a claim to carryback losses incurred in 2002 to the tax years 1999 and 2000. This
resulted in a refund of approximately $3.1&nbsp;million, of which substantially all was received in the
fourth quarter of 2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">59
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Composition of Deferred Tax Items</I></B>:


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred income taxes reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences between the
carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used
for income tax purposes. As of December&nbsp;31, the significant components of the Company&#146;s deferred
tax assets and liabilities are a result of the temporary differences related to the items described
as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS No.&nbsp;109, <I>&#147;Accounting for Income Taxes,&#148; </I>requires that a valuation allowance be
established when it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that all or a portion of deferred tax assets will
not be realized. A review of all available positive and negative evidence needs to be considered,
including the company&#146;s performance, the market environment in which the company operates,
forecasts of future profitability, the utilization of past tax credits, length of carryforward
periods and similar factors. SFAS No.&nbsp;109 further states that it is difficult to conclude that a
valuation allowance is not needed when there is negative evidence such as cumulative losses in
recent years. Therefore, cumulative losses weigh heavily in the overall assessment.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company was in a cumulative loss position three out of four years between December&nbsp;31,
2001 through December&nbsp;31, 2004, which weighed heavily in the overall determination that a valuation
allowance was needed. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company had recorded a valuation allowance of
$129.0&nbsp;million against its net deferred tax assets. The Company expects to continue to record a
full valuation allowance on any future tax benefits until we have achieved several quarters of
consecutive profitable results coupled with an expectation of continued profitability. As of
December&nbsp;2004 and 2003, the valuation allowance totaled $129.0&nbsp;million and $96.5&nbsp;million,
respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>8. Capital Stock</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Preferred Stock</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s Board of Directors by resolution may authorize the issuance of the preferred
stock as a class, in one or more series, having the number of shares, designations, relative voting
rights, dividend rights, liquidation and other preferences and limitations that the Board of
Directors fixes, without any stockholder approval. No shares of preferred stock have been issued.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Common Stock</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The holders of Class&nbsp;A common stock are entitled to fifty votes per share, and the holders of
Class&nbsp;B common stock are entitled to one vote per share, on all matters submitted to a vote of
common stockholders except that voting rights of non-U.S. citizens are limited. The Class&nbsp;A common
stock is convertible into an equal number of Class&nbsp;B shares at any time at the election of the
holders of the Class&nbsp;A common stock. Holdings&#146; Class&nbsp;B common stock is listed on the New York
Stock Exchange.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">60
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holders of common stock of all classes participate equally as to any dividends or
distributions on the common stock, except that dividends payable in shares of common stock, or
securities to acquire common stock, will be made in the same class of common stock as that held by
the recipient of the dividend. Holders of common stock have no right to cumulate their votes in
the election of directors. The common stock votes together as a single class, subject to the right
to a separate class vote in certain instances required by law.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Treasury Stock</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;1995, Holdings adopted a stock repurchase program. The program was amended in
December&nbsp;1995, August&nbsp;1997, August&nbsp;1998, May&nbsp;1999 and February&nbsp;2000. During 1995 through 2000,
Holdings repurchased approximately 16.5&nbsp;million shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock and 7.4&nbsp;million
warrants to purchase Class&nbsp;B common stock. Holdings has not repurchased any Class&nbsp;B common stock
during the last four fiscal years. Holdings&#146; stock repurchase program expired on December&nbsp;31,
2002. The terms of the government guaranteed loan restricted the Company&#146;s ability to repurchase
shares of its stock prior to repayment of the loan in full.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March and April&nbsp;2004, Holdings reacquired 153,680 shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock from a
former executive in payment for approximately $1.7&nbsp;million of nonrecourse loans made by Holdings
between 1994 and 1997.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Warrants</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As compensation for various elements of the Company&#146;s financial restructuring completed in
January&nbsp;2002, Holdings issued a warrant to purchase 18.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock
to the federal government and additional warrants to purchase 3.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B
common stock to other loan participants, in each case at an exercise price of $3 per share and a
term of ten years. For accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at $35.4&nbsp;million, or $1.57
per share, using the Black-Scholes pricing model with the following assumptions: expected dividend
yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of 4.8%, volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten
years. This amount has been recorded in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets, classified
as <I>&#147;Other Assets, Net,&#148; </I>and will be amortized over the life of the government guaranteed loan as an
increase to interest expense. In the first quarter of 2004, approximately 220,000 warrant were
exercised at $3 per share. In the third quarter of 2003, approximately 2.6&nbsp;million warrants were
exercised at $3 per share. These warrant exercises were cashless transactions resulting in the
issuance of approximately 1.6&nbsp;million shares of Holdings&#146; Class&nbsp;B common stock.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>9. Stock Options and Awards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the 1994 Incentive Equity Plan, as amended (the &#147;1994 Incentive Plan&#148;), the Company&#146;s
Board of Directors (the &#147;Board&#148;) was authorized to grant stock options to officers and key
employees. The maximum number of shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock authorized for issuance under the
Plan was 9.0&nbsp;million shares.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of March&nbsp;27, 2002, only 205,831 shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common stock remained
available for future grants under the 1994 Incentive Plan. As of that date, although awards
covering an aggregate of 6,799,570 shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock remained outstanding under the
1994 Incentive Plan, all options granted prior to December&nbsp;31, 2001 were significantly
out-of-the-money (based on the $5.55 per share closing price of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common stock
as reported on the New York Stock Exchange on March&nbsp;27, 2002) due to the significant drop in the
price of the Company&#146;s stock during 2001 (largely as a result of the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001
and its aftermath). Consequently, these options had lost substantially all value as retention and
incentive tools. The Board is strongly opposed to repricing outstanding stock options and, in
connection with the government guaranteed loan, the Company agreed not to reprice any outstanding
stock options so long as the loan remains outstanding.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For these reasons, on March&nbsp;27, 2002, the Board adopted the Company&#146;s 2002 Incentive Equity
Plan (the &#147;2002 Incentive Plan&#148;). A total of 8.0&nbsp;million shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock, which the
Company believes will be adequate to fund the requirements under its long-term compensation
arrangements through 2005, have been reserved for issuance under the 2002 Incentive Plan. At the
same time, the Board determined that, regardless of share availability, no new awards will be
granted under the 1994 Incentive Plan following stockholder approval of the 2002 Incentive Plan.
In May&nbsp;2002, the Company&#146;s stockholders approved the adoption of the 2002 Incentive Plan.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock options are granted with an exercise price equal to the stock&#146;s fair market value at the
date of grant, generally become exercisable over a three-year period and expire if unexercised at
the end of 10&nbsp;years. At December&nbsp;31, 2004, approximately 2.5&nbsp;million shares are available for
grant under the 2002 Incentive Plan.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">61
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
