<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There were 4,959,604 and 4,669,601 stock options exercisable as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 and
December&nbsp;31, 2002, respectively. The per share weighted-average fair value of stock options
granted during 2004, 2003 and 2002 was $4.50, $2.03 and $2.87, respectively, on the date of grant
using the Black-Scholes option pricing model with the following weighted-average assumptions: 2004
- - expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of 3.4%, volatility of 54.0% and an
expected life of five years; 2003 &#151; expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of
2.8%, volatility of 70.4% and an expected life of five years; 2002 &#151; expected dividend yield of
0.0%, risk-free interest rate of 3.9%, volatility of 87.9% and an expected life of four years.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There were no restricted stock grants in the last three fiscal years. The Company recognized
compensation expense of $0.1&nbsp;million, $1.1&nbsp;million and $0.7&nbsp;million related to restricted stock
grants under the 1994 Incentive Plan in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2004,
135,342 shares of restricted stock were vested.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The stock option plans also provide for the issuance of stock and grant of stock options to
non-employee directors. The Company has granted options to purchase 563,000 shares of Class&nbsp;B
common stock to members of the Board of Directors who are not employees of the Company. The
options have a ten-year term and are exercisable six months after the date of grant. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2004, 409,000 options were outstanding and exercisable at prices ranging from $1.93 to
$29.19 per share. There were no grants of Class&nbsp;B common stock to non-employee directors in 2004
or 2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">62
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>10. Employee Benefit Plan</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has a 401(k) defined contribution plan, covering essentially all employees of the
Company. Participants may contribute from 1 to 50% of their pretax earnings to a maximum of
$13,000 in 2004. The Company&#146;s matching contribution is determined annually by the Board of
Directors. The Company&#146;s contribution expense to the plan totaled $11.4&nbsp;million, $8.7&nbsp;million and
$8.7&nbsp;million in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the third quarter of 2004, the Company became aware that an insufficient number of
shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock were registered for offer and sale through its 401(k) plan. In
response to this registration shortfall, the Company promptly filed a new registration statement on
Form S-8 on August&nbsp;13, 2004, which registered an additional 4,500,000 shares of Class&nbsp;B common
stock to permit the continued offer and sale of such shares to participants through the 401(k)
plan. Because the 401(k) plan in the past has purchased and in the future expects to continue to
purchase shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock needed for allocation to participant accounts only in the
open market and not directly from the Company, the registration of these additional shares and
their purchase by the 401(k) plan will have no dilutive impact on the outstanding equity of the
Company. As a result of the registration shortfall, however, participants who acquired
unregistered shares through their 401(k) plan accounts after June&nbsp;30, 2003, and prior to August&nbsp;13,
2004, may be entitled to rescission rights or other remedies under the Securities Act of 1933, as
amended. The Company has notified affected existing and former plan participants of their
potential rescission rights, but cannot predict the extent to which any such rescission rights may
be exercised or the impact of any possible federal or state regulatory action pertaining to the
registration shortfall. The Company does not believe, however, that any consequences arising from
the registration shortfall will have a material adverse effect on its financial position or results
of operations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>11. Special Charges</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2004, the Company recorded a $0.6&nbsp;million reduction in special charges
related to the revision of estimated costs associated with the sale and leaseback of certain
aircraft.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2004, the Company entered into definitive agreements with two lessors to return six
Boeing 737-200 aircraft. Three of these aircraft were returned to the lessors in the third
quarter, two were returned in the fourth quarter and one was returned in January&nbsp;2005. In
addition, the Company continues negotiating with one lessor on the return of its remaining two
Boeing 737-200 aircraft, one of which was parked in March&nbsp;2002. The other aircraft was removed
from service in January&nbsp;2005. In connection with the return of the aircraft, the Company recorded
$1.9&nbsp;million of special charges which include lease termination payment of $2.1&nbsp;million, the
write-down of leasehold improvements and aircraft rent balance of $2.8&nbsp;million, offset by the net
reversal of maintenance reserves of $3.0&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the Company and General Electric (&#147;GE&#148;) mutually agreed to terminate the
V2500 A-1 power by hour (PBH)&nbsp;agreement effective January&nbsp;1, 2005. This agreement was entered into
March&nbsp;1998 with an original term of ten years. For terminating the agreement early, the Company
received a $20.0&nbsp;million credit to be applied to amounts due for other engines under the 1998
agreement that is expected to be fully applied by December&nbsp;31, 2005. The Company had capitalized
PBH payments for V2500 A-1 engines in excess of the unamortized cost of the overhauls performed by
GE of approximately $3.7&nbsp;million. With the termination of this agreement, these payments were not
realizable and as a result, the Company wrote off this amount against the $20.0&nbsp;million credit
referred to above resulting in a $16.3&nbsp;million net gain.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2003, AWA announced the elimination of its hub operations in Columbus, Ohio. As a
result, 12 regional jets, all of which were operated by Chautauqua Airlines under the America West
Express banner, have been phased out of the fleet. In addition, the hub has been downsized from 49
daily departures to 15 destinations to four flights per day to Phoenix and Las Vegas. Service to
New York City La Guardia Airport was also eliminated because perimeter rules at the airport
prohibit flights beyond 1,500 miles, precluding service from AWA&#146;s hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas.
In the first and second quarters of 2003, the Company recorded special charges of $1.0&nbsp;million and
$9.6&nbsp;million, respectively, related to the costs associated with the termination of certain
aircraft and facility contracts, employee transfer and severance expenses and the write-off of
leasehold improvements in Columbus, Ohio.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2003, the Company recorded a $1.1&nbsp;million reduction in special charges
related to the earlier-than-planned return of certain leased aircraft in 2001 and 2002, as all
payments related to these aircraft returns have been made.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">63
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2003, as part of a cost reduction program, the Company implemented a plan to reduce
management, professional and administrative payroll costs which resulted in 179 fewer employees
within these workgroups. As a result, the Company recorded a special charge of $2.3&nbsp;million
related to this reduction-in-force.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2003, the Company recorded an impairment loss of $2.6&nbsp;million related to three owned
Boeing 737-200 aircraft that were grounded and subsequently sold.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter of 2003, the Company recorded an additional $0.5&nbsp;million of special
charges associated with the elimination of our hub operations in Columbus, Ohio. These special
charges were offset by a $0.5&nbsp;million reduction in special charges related to the revision of
estimated costs associated with the sale and leaseback of certain aircraft.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2002, the Company recorded a special charge of $21.1&nbsp;million,
primarily related to the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002, resulting from the events of
September&nbsp;11, 2001. Components of the special charge are as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of this amount, approximately $10.3&nbsp;million, principally related to losses on

accrued.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter of 2002, the Company recorded a $2.0&nbsp;million reduction in special charges
due to a revision of the estimated costs related to the early termination of certain aircraft
leases.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">64

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company expects to make payments related to these special charges through the fourth
quarter of 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>12. Nonoperating Income (Expenses) &#151; Other, Net</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the term loan refinancing with GECC, the Company wrote off $1.3&nbsp;million of
debt issue costs associated to the term loan with Mizuho in 2004. This amount was recorded in
nonoperating expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The changes in the fair value of the Company&#146;s derivative instruments and the net realized
gains and losses for the settled hedge transactions was a $30.5&nbsp;million credit in 2004, $10.7
million credit in 2003 and $0.6&nbsp;million expense in 2002.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2003, the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America passed,
and the President signed, the Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act to provide certain
aviation-related assistance. $2.3&nbsp;billion of the appropriation was for grants by the TSA to U.S.
air carriers based on the proportional share each carrier had paid or collected as of the date of
enactment of the legislation for passenger security and air carrier security fees. In May&nbsp;2003,
AWA received approximately $81.3&nbsp;million representing its proportional share of passenger security
and air carrier security fees paid or collected as of April&nbsp;2003, which has been classified as
<I>&#147;Federal Government Assistance&#148; </I>in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations. See
Note 17, <I>&#147;Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the fourth quarter of 2003, IAC/InterActiveCorp completed its acquisition of Hotwire.com, a
discount travel website. Hotwire was founded by the Texas Pacific Group, American Airlines,
Continental Airlines, Northwest Airlines, United Airlines, US Airways and AWA in October&nbsp;2000. AWA
had an ownership interest of approximately 1.5% in Hotwire.com with a carrying value of
approximately $0.03&nbsp;million. Upon closing of the transaction, AWA received cash of $9.8&nbsp;million.
Accordingly, AWA recognized a nonoperating gain of $9.8&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the fourth quarter of 2003, Holdings completed the sale of its 12% interest in National
Leisure Group to PAR Capital. The investment in National Leisure Group was carried on the
Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheet at cost, which approximated $7.7&nbsp;million. PAR Capital owned
$10.45&nbsp;million face value of the Company&#146;s 10 3/4% senior unsecured notes. PAR Capital purchased the
Company&#146;s investment in National Leisure Group in exchange for the $10.45&nbsp;million face value of the
10 3/4% notes plus $0.3&nbsp;million in cash. This resulted in a $3.3&nbsp;million nonoperating gain. See
Note 4, <I>&#147;Financial Instruments and Risk Management &#150; (a)&nbsp;Fair Value of Financial Instruments &#150;
Investments in Equity Securities.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the airline compensation provisions of the Air Transportation Safety and System
Stabilization Act (the &#147;Act&#148;), each air carrier was entitled to receive the lesser of: (i)&nbsp;its
direct and incremental losses for the period September&nbsp;11, 2001 to December&nbsp;31, 2001 or (ii)&nbsp;its
proportional available seat mile allocation (based on available seat miles for August&nbsp;2001) of the
$4.5&nbsp;billion compensation available under the Act. In 2001, AWA received $98.2&nbsp;million under the
Act from the United States government and expected to receive, based on its losses and its share of
available seat miles, at least an additional $10.0&nbsp;million. In accordance with EITF Issue No.
01-10, <I>&#147;Accounting for the Impact of the Terrorist Attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001,&#148; </I>AWA recognized
$108.2&nbsp;million of federal government assistance in 2001 as nonoperating income because direct and
incremental losses incurred during 2001 exceeded that amount. In July&nbsp;2002, AWA received an
additional $12.3&nbsp;million under the Act. Accordingly, $10.0&nbsp;million was credited against the
receivable established in 2001 and $2.3&nbsp;million was recognized as nonoperating income in the second
quarter of 2002. In August&nbsp;2002, AWA received an additional payment of $6.2&nbsp;million under the Act,
which was recognized as nonoperating income in the third quarter of 2002.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March&nbsp;2002, the Company wrote down its investment in Aeroxchange, an e-commerce entity,
which was carried at cost, to net realizable value recognizing a loss of $2.8&nbsp;million.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">65
</DIV>

</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 5,248,891 stock options and 7,352,988 warrants
issued in conjunction with the government guaranteed loan and related transactions are not included
in the computation of diluted EPS because the option and warrant exercise prices were greater than
the average market price of common stock for the period. In addition, 8,095,842 shares issuable
upon conversion of the 7.25% senior exchangeable notes due 2023 and 8,694,000 issuable upon
conversion of the 7.5% convertible senior notes are not included in the computation of diluted EPS
because of the antidilutive effect on EPS.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 5,256,111 stock options and 11,410,318 warrants issued
in conjunction with the government guaranteed loan and related transactions are not included in the
computation of diluted EPS because the option and warrant exercise prices were greater than the
average market price of common stock for the period. In November&nbsp;2004, the Emerging Issues Task
Force (&#147;EITF&#148;) of the FASB reached a consensus on EITF 04-08, <I>&#147;The Effect of Contingently
Convertible Instruments on Diluted Earnings per Share,&#148; </I>which requires that issuers of convertible
securities with contingent conversion features use the &#147;if-converted&#148; method to calculate reported
earnings per share (&#147;EPS&#148;) irrespective of the contingent conversion trigger being met. As
approved by the FASB, this change is effective for years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2004. The
Company applied this methodology in the accompanying consolidated statement of operations. The
impact of using the &#147;if-converted&#148; method for the Company&#146;s 7.25% Notes is antidilutive for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2002. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, the inclusion of the
7.25% Notes reduced diluted EPS by $0.03 from $1.29 to $1.26.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">66
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 22,074 stock options and 2,794,399 warrants issued in
conjunction with the government guaranteed loan and related transactions are not included in the
computation of diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on EPS. In addition, 7,292,706 stock
options and 19,742,601 warrants are not included in the computation of diluted EPS because the
option and warrant exercise prices were greater than the average market price of common stock for
the period. The shares issuable upon conversion of the 7.5% convertible senior notes are not
included in the computation of diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect on EPS.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>15. Related Party Transactions</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of AWA&#146;s reorganization in 1994, Continental Airlines and AWA entered into an alliance
agreement that included code sharing arrangements, reciprocal frequent flyer programs and ground
handling operations. In March&nbsp;2002, AWA received notice from Continental of its intention to
terminate the code sharing and frequent flyer agreements between the two airlines, effective April
26, 2002. Two of Continental&#146;s directors are managing partners of Texas Pacific Group, which,
through TPG Advisors, Inc., effectively controls the voting power of Holdings. AWA paid
Continental approximately $13.4&nbsp;million, $17.3&nbsp;million and $25.5&nbsp;million and also received
approximately $4.1&nbsp;million, $5.0&nbsp;million and $15.9&nbsp;million in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively,
from Continental pursuant to these agreements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Texas Pacific Group agreed to reimburse the Company approximately $2.5&nbsp;million for expenses
incurred by the Company on its behalf. As a result, the Company recorded this as a receivable as
of December&nbsp;31, 2004. Subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2004, the Company received $1.3&nbsp;million in such
reimbursement and expects to receive an additional $1.2&nbsp;million in 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>16. Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited)</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The 2004 and 2003 unaudited quarterly financial data has been restated to reflect the
accounting for fuel hedging derivative instruments pursuant to management&#146;s determination that the
Company did not qualify for hedge accounting under SFAS No.&nbsp;133. In addition, the restated amounts
also reflect corrections to properly reflect the fair value of open derivative instruments at each
quarter end. See Note 2, <I>&#147;Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts.&#148;</I>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">67
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings per share are computed independently for each of the quarters presented.
Therefore, the sum of the quarterly earnings per share in 2004 and 2003 does not equal the total
computed for the year.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>17. Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2003, the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America passed,
and the President signed, the Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act to provide certain
aviation-related assistance. The bill included the following key provisions:


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>$2.3&nbsp;billion of the appropriation was for grants by the Transportation Security
Administration (&#147;TSA&#148;) to U.S. air carriers based on the proportional share each carrier
had paid or collected as of the date of enactment of the legislation for passenger security
and air carrier security fees. In May&nbsp;2003, the Company received approximately $81.3
million representing its proportional share of passenger security and air carrier security
fees paid or collected as of April&nbsp;2003. The Company recorded this amount as nonoperating
income in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations. See Note 12,
<I>&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expenses) &#150; Other, Net.&#148;</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The TSA would not impose passenger security fees during the period beginning June&nbsp;1,
2003 and ending September&nbsp;30, 2003.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>$100&nbsp;million of the appropriation would be available to compensate air carriers for the
direct costs associated with the strengthening of flight deck doors and locks on aircraft.
AWA received approximately $4.6&nbsp;million in 2003 as reimbursement for the costs of
reinforcing flight deck doors and locks.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Aviation war risk insurance provided by the federal government is extended until August
2005.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">69
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">



</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Certain airlines that received the aviation-related assistance, principally those
airlines with trans-Pacific or trans-Atlantic flights, agreed to limit the total cash
compensation for certain executive officers during the 12-month period beginning April&nbsp;1,
2003 to an amount equal to the annual salary paid to that officer during the air carrier&#146;s
fiscal year 2002. Any violation of this agreement would have required the carrier to repay
to the government the amount reimbursed for airline security fees. Since AWA does not
operate trans-Pacific or trans-Atlantic flights, AWA was not subject to this provision.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>18. Segment Disclosures</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holdings is one reportable operating segment. Accordingly, the segment reporting financial
data required by SFAS No.&nbsp;131 is included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and
consolidated statements of operations.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">70
</DIV>

AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC. (&#147;AWA&#148;)</B></DIV>

consolidated statements of operations, cash flows and stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income
for each of the years in the three-year period ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, together with the related
notes and the reports of KPMG LLP, and PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, independent registered public
accounting firms, are set forth on the following pages.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">71

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholder</B><BR>
<B>America West Airlines, Inc.:</B>



<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt">We
have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of America
West Airlines, Inc. and subsidiary as of
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, and the related consolidated statements of operations, cash flows and
stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income for the years then ended. These consolidated
financial statements are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility is to
express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.


<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt">We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight
Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An
audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the
financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and
significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement
presentation. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.


<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt">In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all
material respects, the financial position of America West Airlines,
Inc. and subsidiary as of December&nbsp;31, 2004
and 2003, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for the years then ended, in
conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.


<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt">As discussed in Note 2 to the accompanying consolidated financial statements, the Company has
restated the consolidated balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 and the consolidated statement of
changes in stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income for the year then ended.


<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt">/s/ KPMG LLP


<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt">Phoenix, Arizona<BR>
March&nbsp;11, 2005


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">72
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM</B>



<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholder<BR>
of America West Airlines, Inc.:</B>


<P align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt">In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated statements of operations, of cash flows and of
stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 present fairly,
in all material respects, the results of operations and cash flows of America West Airlines, Inc.
(a wholly-owned subsidiary of America West Holdings Corporation) for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility
is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audit. We conducted our audit
of these statements in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight
Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An
audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the
financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by
management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that our audit
provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">As discussed in Note&nbsp;1(k) to the consolidated financial statements,
 the Company changed its method of accounting for reorganization value in excess
 of amounts allocable to identifiable assets  in connection with the adoption of Statement of Financial
 Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;142, &#147;<i>Goodwill and Other
Intangible Assets,</I>&#148; effective January&nbsp;1, 2002.

    <TD nowrap>)</TD>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<BR>
DECEMBER 31, 2004, 2003 AND 2002</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;America West Airlines, Inc. (&#147;AWA&#148; or the &#147;Airline&#148;) is a wholly owned subsidiary of America
West Holdings Corporation (&#147;Holdings&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;). AWA accounted for most of the Company&#146;s
revenues and expenses in 2004. Based on 2004 operating revenues and available seat miles (&#147;ASMs&#148;),
AWA is the eighth largest passenger airline in the United States with the lowest cost structure of
the eight major hub-and-spoke airlines. At the end of 2004, AWA operated a fleet of 138 aircraft
with an average fleet age of 10.7&nbsp;years and served 63 destinations in North America, including
eight in Mexico, three in Canada and one in Costa Rica. Through regional alliance and code share
arrangements with other airlines, AWA served an additional 51 destinations in North America and the
Middle East. In 2004, AWA flew approximately 21.1&nbsp;million passengers and generated revenues of
approximately $2.3&nbsp;billion.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(a)&nbsp;Basis of Presentation</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of America West Airlines and its
wholly owned subsidiary Flight Training Center Hangar Plan (&#147;FTCHP&#148;). All significant intercompany
balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. Certain reclassifications have
been made to prior years&#146; consolidated financial statements to conform to the current year&#146;s
presentation.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Leisure Company (&#147;TLC&#148;), previously a wholly owned subsidiary of Holdings, was merged into
AWA on January&nbsp;1, 2004 and continues to operate as the America West Vacations division of AWA.
This transaction was accounted for as a reorganization of entities under common control. The 2003
and 2002 consolidated financial statements are presented on a comparable basis with the 2004
consolidated financial statements, as if the reorganization had occurred January&nbsp;1, 2002. All
intercompany transactions between AWA and TLC have been eliminated.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(b)&nbsp;Cash, Cash Equivalents and Short-term Investments</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash equivalents consist of all highly liquid debt instruments purchased with original
maturities of three months or less. Short-term investments consist of cash invested in certain
debt securities with original maturities greater than 90&nbsp;days and less than one year. The debt
securities are classified as held to maturity and are carried at amortized cost that approximates
fair value.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA reclassified investments in auction rate securities previously classified as cash
equivalents to short-term investments on the accompanying consolidated balance sheets. Investments
reclassified in 2004 and 2003 were $58.4&nbsp;million and $249.7&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(c)&nbsp;Expendable Spare Parts and Supplies</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight equipment expendable spare parts and supplies are valued at average cost. An allowance
for obsolescence is provided, over the estimated useful life of the related aircraft and engines,
for spare parts expected to be on hand at the date the aircraft are retired from service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(d)&nbsp;Property and Equipment</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property and equipment are recorded at cost. Interest capitalized on advance payments for
aircraft acquisitions and on expenditures for aircraft improvements are part of these costs.
Interest capitalized for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 was $2.2&nbsp;million, $1.6
million and $3.0&nbsp;million, respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and amortized to
residual values over the estimated useful lives or the lease term, whichever is less, using the
straight-line method.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The estimated useful lives for AWA&#146;s ground property and equipment range from three to 12
years for owned property and equipment and up to 30&nbsp;years for the flight training facility. The
estimated useful lives of AWA&#146;s owned aircraft, jet engines, flight equipment and rotable parts
range from five to 25&nbsp;years. Leasehold improvements relating to flight equipment and other
property on operating leases are amortized over the life of the lease or the life of the asset,
whichever is shorter.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">78
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA records impairment losses on long-lived assets used in operations when events and
circumstances indicate that the assets might be impaired as defined by SFAS No.&nbsp;144, <I>&#147;Accounting
for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets.&#148; </I>Recoverability of assets to be held and used
is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of an asset to undiscounted future net cash
flows expected to be generated by the asset. If such assets are considered to be impaired, the
impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying amount of the assets
exceeds the fair value of the assets. Assets to be disposed of are reported at the lower of the
carrying amount or fair value less cost to sell.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(e)&nbsp;Restricted Cash</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted cash includes cash deposits securing certain letters of credit and surety bonds and
cash deposits held by institutions that process credit card sales transactions. Current restricted
cash includes amounts set aside in an irrevocable trust for the redemption of the 10 <FONT style="font-size: 70%"><SUP>3</SUP></FONT>/<FONT style="font-size: 60%">4</FONT>% senior
unsecured notes which was subsequently paid on January&nbsp;26, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(f)&nbsp;Aircraft Maintenance and Repairs</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Routine maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred. The cost of major
scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhauls are capitalized and amortized over the
periods benefited and are included in aircraft maintenance materials and repairs expense.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2004, the Company revised the estimated useful life for certain
aircraft and related spare parts inventory as a result of changes in AWA&#146;s fleet plan and for
capitalized maintenance on certain of its engines as a result of changes in aircraft utilization.
The net impact of this change in estimate decreased the net loss for 2004 by approximately $18.4
million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An accrual for the estimated cost of scheduled airframe and engine overhauls required to be
performed on leased aircraft prior to their return to the lessors has also been recorded. These
estimates are based on historical costs and our assumptions regarding the renewal of aircraft
leases.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(g)&nbsp;Derivative Instruments</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA&#146;s fuel hedging contracts do not qualify as cash flow hedges under Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;133, <I>&#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&#148; </I>(&#147;SFAS
No.&nbsp;133&#148;). See Note 2, <I>&#147;Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts.&#148; </I>Accordingly, the derivative
hedging instruments are recorded as an asset or liability on the balance sheet at fair value and
the changes in the fair values are recorded in <I>&#147;Gain (Loss) on Derivative Instruments, Net</I>&#148; in the
accompanying consolidated statements of operations. See Note 12, <I>&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expenses) &#151;
Other, Net.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(h)&nbsp;Frequent Flyer Awards</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA maintains a frequent travel award program known as &#147;FlightFund&#148; that provides a variety of
awards to program members based on accumulated mileage. The estimated cost of providing the free
travel, using the incremental cost method as adjusted for estimated redemption rates, is recognized
as a liability and charged to operations as program members accumulate mileage.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA also sells mileage credits to companies participating in its FlightFund program, such as
hotels, car rental agencies and credit card companies. Transportation-related revenue from the
sale of mileage credits is deferred and recognized when transportation is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(i)&nbsp;Deferred Credit-Operating Leases</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rents for operating leases were adjusted to fair market value when AWA emerged from bankruptcy
in 1994. The net present value of the difference between the stated lease rates and the fair
market rates has been recorded as a deferred credit in the accompanying balance sheets. The
deferred credit will be increased through charges to interest expense and decreased on a
straight-line basis as a reduction in rent expense over the applicable lease periods. At December
31, 2004 and 2003, the unamortized balance of the deferred credit was $38.3&nbsp;million and $44.6
million, respectively.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">79
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380&nbsp;million government loan
guarantee. This loan triggered aircraft rent concessions negotiated with approximately 20 aircraft
lessors. Approximately $18.1&nbsp;million of aircraft rent, which was accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2001,
was waived by the aircraft lessors. This amount has been recorded as a deferred credit in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheet and will be amortized over the remaining lives of the
applicable leases as a reduction in rent expense. At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the unamortized
balance of the deferred credit was approximately $4.2&nbsp;million and $7.8&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(j)&nbsp;Passenger Revenue</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided. Ticket sales for
transportation which has not yet been provided are recorded as air traffic liability. Passenger
traffic commissions and related fees are expensed when the related revenue is recognized.
Passenger traffic commissions and related fees not yet recognized are included as a prepaid
expense. Due to complex pricing structures, refund and exchange policies, and interline agreements
with other airlines, certain amounts are recognized in revenue using estimates regarding both the
timing of the revenue recognition and the amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates are
generally based on the statistical analysis of AWA&#146;s historical data. Any adjustments resulting
from periodic evaluations of the estimated air traffic liability are included in results of
operations during the period in which the evaluations are completed.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(k)&nbsp;Reorganization
Value in Excess of Amounts Allocable to Identifiable Assets (&#147;ERV&#148;)</I></B>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June 2001, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;142, <I>&#147;Goodwill and
Other Intangible Assets.&#148;</I> SFAS No.&nbsp;142 primarily
addresses the accounting for goodwill and intangible assets
subsequent to their acquisition. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 does not permit
the amortization of goodwill as required by APB Opinion No.&nbsp;17,
<I>&#147;Intangible Assets.&#148;</I> Rather, goodwill is subject to
a periodic impairment test, using a two-step process. The first step
is to identify a potential impairment. The second step of the
goodwill impairment test measures the amount of the impairment loss,
using a fair value-based approach. Under SFAS No.&nbsp;142, ERV is
reported as goodwill and accounted for in the same manner as
goodwill. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 was effective for fiscal years beginning
after December&nbsp;15, 2001. Upon adoption of this statement on
January&nbsp;1, 2002, AWA recorded an impairment loss of
$208.2&nbsp;million, which was supported by an independent valuation
of the Company. The impairment loss was recorded as the cumulative
effect of a change in accounting principle.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(l)&nbsp;Advertising Costs</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA expenses the costs of advertising as incurred. Advertising expense for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 was $8.3&nbsp;million, $5.8&nbsp;million and $6.5&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(m)&nbsp;Income Taxes</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method. Deferred tax assets and
liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the
financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax
bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards. A valuation allowance is established, if
necessary, for the amount of any tax benefits that, based on available evidence, are not expected
to be realized.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(n)&nbsp;Stock Options</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain of AWA&#146;s employees are eligible to participate in the stock option plans of Holdings.
Holdings accounts for its stock option plans in accordance with the provisions of APB Opinion No.
25, <I>&#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; </I>and related interpretations. As such, compensation
expense would be recorded on the date of grant only if the current market price of the underlying
stock exceeded the exercise price. Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for stock
options in Holdings&#146; condensed consolidated financial statements. Had Holdings determined
compensation cost based on the fair value at the grant date for its stock options under SFAS No.
123, <I>&#147;Accounting for Share-Based Payments,&#148; </I>and allocated the compensation expense to AWA for its
employees participating in the stock option plans, AWA&#146;s net income (loss)&nbsp;would have been reduced
to the pro forma amounts indicated below:

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(o)&nbsp;New Accounting Standards</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Revised Statement No.&nbsp;123, <I>&#147;Accounting for Share-Based
Payment&#148; </I>(&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;123R&#148;). This statement requires AWA to recognize the grant-date fair value of
stock options in the Statement of Operations. In addition, AWA will be required to calculate this
compensation using the fair-value based method, versus the intrinsic value method previously
allowed under SFAS No.&nbsp;123. This revision is effective for periods beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2005.
Accordingly, AWA will adopt this revised SFAS effective July&nbsp;1, 2005. AWA is currently evaluating
how it will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;123R and has not determined the method it will use to value granted
stock options. The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R is expected to have a material effect on AWA&#146;s
results of operations. See Note 1, <I>&#147;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&#148; </I>(m) <I>&#147;Stock
Options&#148; </I>for AWA&#146;s disclosure of the impact of the compensation cost associated with stock options
under SFAS No.&nbsp;123.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(p)&nbsp;Use of Estimates</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management of AWA has made certain estimates and assumptions relating to the reporting of
assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities to prepare these
consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in
the United States. Actual results could differ from those estimates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(q)&nbsp;Reclassifications</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain reclassifications have been made to the prior years&#146; consolidated financial statements
to conform to the current year&#146;s presentation.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA reclassified amounts related to settled fuel hedge transactions and mark-to-market
adjustments on open hedge instruments from <I>&#147;Aircraft Fuel&#148; </I>expense to <I>&#147;Gain (Loss) on Derivative
Instruments, Net&#148; </I>in the accompanying consolidated statement of operations. In fiscal years 2004
and 2003, such amounts reduced fuel expense while in fiscal years 2002 and 2001, such amounts
increased fuel expense, as originally classified. The amounts reclassified are as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>2. Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Derivative Instruments</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In February 2005, management
undertook a review of AWA&#146;s accounting for its fuel hedging
transactions. As a result of this review, management concluded that
AWA&#146;s hedging transactions did not qualify for hedge accounting
under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Accordingly,
management concluded that the financial statements for prior periods
required restatement to reflect the fair value of fuel hedging
contracts in the balance sheets and statements of stockholders equity
and comprehensive income of Holdings and AWA. Specifically,
(i)&nbsp;AWA has restated its balance sheet and statement of
stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income as of and for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, and (ii)&nbsp;AWA has restated its
2004 and 2003 interim financial results to correct the aforementioned
accounting errors. The unaudited interim results as originally
reported and as restated are presented in Note&nbsp;15,
&#147;<I>Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited)</I>.&#148; AWA restated
its 2003 consolidated balance sheet to reduce the carrying value of
its derivative instruments asset by $12.5&nbsp;million, which served
to record the asset at fair value of open contracts as of
December&nbsp;31, 2003. The restatement also eliminated
$12.5&nbsp;million in accumulated other comprehensive income,
$2.0&nbsp;million of which was previously recorded in the 2003
beginning balance of accumulated other comprehensive income. The
restated amount of other assets is $110.2&nbsp;million in the
accompanying 2003 consolidated balance sheet. The restatement
eliminates the balance in accumulated other comprehensive income in
the accompanying 2003 consolidated balance sheet and consolidated
statement of stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">81
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, AWA had long-term investments in debt securities of $30.0&nbsp;million and $40.7
million as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. Long-term investments consist of cash
invested in certain debt securities with maturities greater than one year. The debt securities are
classified as held to maturity and are carried at amortized cost that approximates fair value.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>4. Financial Instruments and Risk Management</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(a)&nbsp;Fair Value of Financial Instruments</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash Equivalents, Short-term Investments and Receivables</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amount approximates fair value because of the short-term nature of these
instruments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Long-term Debt</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, the fair value of long-term debt was approximately $721.5
million and $845.6&nbsp;million, respectively. AWA&#146;s variable rate long-term debt with a carrying value
of $545.7&nbsp;million and $555.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively, approximates fair
value because these borrowings have variable interest rate terms that approximate market interest
rates for similar debt instruments. The fair values of AWA&#146;s other long-term debt are determined
based on quoted market prices if available or market prices for comparable debt instruments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(b)&nbsp;Fuel Price Risk Management</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under its fuel hedging program, AWA may enter into certain hedging transactions with approved
counterparties for a period generally not exceeding 12&nbsp;months. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, AWA had
entered into costless collar and basis swap transactions hedging approximately 42% of its projected
2005 fuel requirements. The fair value of AWA&#146;s financial derivative instruments was a net asset
of approximately $0.2&nbsp;million and $2.7&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. See
Note 2, <I>&#147;Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts.&#148;</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA is exposed to credit risks in the event any counterparty fails to meet its obligations.
AWA does not anticipate such non-performance as counterparties are selected based on credit
ratings, exposure to any one counterparty is limited based on formal guidelines and the relative
market positions with such counterparties are closely monitored.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(c)&nbsp;Concentration of Credit Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA does not believe it is subject to any significant concentration of credit risk. Most of
AWA&#146;s receivables result from tickets sold to individual passengers through the use of major credit
cards or from tickets sold by other airlines and used by passengers on AWA. These receivables are
short-term, generally being settled shortly after the sale.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">82
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>5. Advances to Parent Company and Affiliate</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380&nbsp;million government loan
guarantee. The terms of this loan and AWA&#146;s secured term loan restrict Holdings&#146; and AWA&#146;s ability
to incur additional indebtedness or issue equity unless the proceeds of those transactions are used
to prepay the government guaranteed loan and the term loan. Accordingly, as a result of this
transaction, AWA&#146;s net advances to Holdings have been classified in &#147;Other Assets&#148; on AWA&#146;s balance
sheet.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA&#146;s net advances to Holdings were approximately $258.8&nbsp;million and $213.1&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade color="#000000">

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">(a)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">On September&nbsp;10, 2004, AWA entered into a term loan financing with GECC
providing for loans in an aggregate amount of $110.6&nbsp;million. AWA used
approximately $77.0&nbsp;million of the proceeds from this financing to repay in full
its term loan with Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd. and certain other lenders and to
pay certain costs associated with this transaction. AWA used the remaining
proceeds for general corporate purposes. The new term loan financing consists of
two secured term loan facilities: a $75.6&nbsp;million term loan facility secured
primarily by spare parts, rotables and appliances (the &#147;Spare Parts Facility&#148;);
and a $35.0&nbsp;million term loan facility secured primarily by aircraft engines and
parts installed in such engines (the &#147;Engine Facility&#148;).</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">The facilities are cross-collateralized on a subordinated basis and the collateral
securing the facilities also secures on a subordinated basis certain of AWA&#146;s other
existing debt and lease obligations to GECC and its affiliates.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">The loans under the Spare Parts Facility are payable in full at maturity on
September&nbsp;10, 2010. The loans under the Engine Facility are payable in equal
quarterly installments of $1.3&nbsp;million beginning on March&nbsp;10, 2006 through June&nbsp;10,
2010 with the remaining loan amount of $11.8&nbsp;million payable at maturity on
September&nbsp;10, 2010. The loans under each facility may be prepaid in an amount not
less than $5&nbsp;million at any time after the 30th monthly anniversary of the funding
date under such facility. If AWA fails to maintain a certain ratio of rotables to
loans under the Spare Parts Facility, it may be required to pledge additional
rotables or cash as collateral, provide a letter of credit or prepay some or all of
the loans under the Spare Parts Facility. In addition, the loans under the Engine
Facility are subject to mandatory prepayment upon the occurrence of certain events
of loss applicable to, or certain dispositions of, aircraft engines securing the
facility.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">83
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">






<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>



<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Principal amounts outstanding under the loans bear interest at a rate per annum
based on three-month LIBOR plus a margin. Both facilities contain customary events
of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults, breach of covenants,
bankruptcy and insolvency defaults and judgment defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On December&nbsp;27, 2004, AWA raised additional capital by financing its Phoenix
maintenance facility and flight training center. The flight training center was
previously unencumbered, and the maintenance facility became unencumbered earlier
this year when AWA refinanced its term loan. Using its leasehold interest in
these two facilities as collateral, AWA, through a wholly owned subsidiary named
FTCHP LLC, raised $30.8&nbsp;million through the issuance of senior secured discount
notes. The notes were issued by FTCHP at a discount pursuant to the terms of a
senior secured term loan agreement among AWA, FTCHP, Heritage Bank, SSB, as
administrative agent, Citibank, N.A., as the initial lender, and the other lenders
from time to time party thereto. Citibank, N.A. subsequently assigned all of its
interests in the notes to third party lenders.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>AWA has fully and unconditionally guaranteed the payment and performance of FTCHP&#146;s
obligations under the notes and the loan agreement. The notes require aggregate
principal payments of $36&nbsp;million with principal payments of $1.5&nbsp;million due on
each of the first two anniversary dates and the remaining principal amount due on
the fifth anniversary date. The notes may be prepaid in full at any time (subject
to customary LIBOR breakage costs) and in partial amounts of $1.5&nbsp;million on the
third and fourth anniversary dates. The unpaid principal amount of the notes bears
interest based on LIBOR plus a margin subject to adjustment based on a loan to
collateral value ratio.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The loan agreement contains customary covenants applicable to loans of this type,
including obligations relating to the preservation of the collateral and
restrictions on the activities of FTCHP. In addition, the loan agreement contains
events of default, including payment defaults, cross-defaults to other debt of
FTCHP, if any, breach of covenants, bankruptcy and insolvency defaults and judgment
defaults.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In connection with this financing, AWA sold all of its leasehold interests in the
maintenance facility and flight training center to FTCHP and entered into subleases
for the facilities with FTCHP at lease rates expected to approximate the interest
payments due under the notes. In addition, AWA agreed to make future capital
contributions to FTCHP in amounts sufficient to cover principal payments and other
amounts owing pursuant to the notes and the loan agreement.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The proceeds from this financing, together with $10.5&nbsp;million from operating cash
flow, were irrevocably deposited with the trustee for AWA&#146;s 10 3/4% senior
unsecured notes due 2005 and subsequently redeemed on January&nbsp;26, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(c)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In January&nbsp;2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a $380&nbsp;million
federal loan guarantee provided by the Air Transportation Stabilization Board (the
&#147;ATSB&#148;). Certain third-party counter-guarantors have fully and unconditionally
guaranteed the payment of an aggregate of $45&nbsp;million of the outstanding principal
amount under the government guaranteed loan plus accrued and unpaid interest
thereon. In addition, Holdings has fully and unconditionally guaranteed the
payment of all principal, premium, interest and other obligations outstanding
under the government guaranteed loan and has pledged the stock of AWA to secure
its obligations under such guarantee. Principal amounts under this loan become
due in ten installments of $42.9&nbsp;million on each March&nbsp;31 and September&nbsp;30,
commencing on March&nbsp;31, 2004 and ending on September&nbsp;30, 2008. Principal amounts
outstanding under the government guaranteed loan bear interest at a rate per annum
equal to LIBOR plus 40 basis points.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Subject to certain exceptions, AWA is required to prepay the government guaranteed
loan with:</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the net proceeds of all issuances of debt or equity by either Holdings or AWA after January&nbsp;2002;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>proceeds from asset sales in excess of $20&nbsp;million in any fiscal year; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>insurance proceeds in excess of $2&nbsp;million to the extent such proceeds are
not used to restore or replace the assets from which such proceeds are
derived.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In addition, AWA is required to prepay the government guaranteed loan upon a change
in control and we may be required to prepay portions of the loan if our employee
compensation costs exceed a certain threshold. AWA may, at its option, prepay the
government guaranteed loan without premium or penalty, subject to reimbursement of
the lenders&#146; breakage costs in the case of prepayment of LIBOR loans.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The government guaranteed loan requires that AWA maintain a minimum cash balance of
$100&nbsp;million. In addition, the government loan contains customary affirmative
covenants and the following negative covenants: restrictions on liens, investments,
restricted payments, fundamental changes, asset sales and acquisitions, the
creation of new subsidiaries, sale and leasebacks, transactions with affiliates,
the conduct of business, mergers or consolidations, issuances and dispositions of
capital stock of subsidiaries, and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>

    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>amendments to other indebtedness. The government guaranteed loan contains

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(d)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In August&nbsp;1995, AWA issued $75.0&nbsp;million principal
amount of 10 3/4% senior
unsecured notes due 2005 of which $39.5&nbsp;million remained outstanding at December
31, 2004. Interest on the 10 3/4% senior unsecured notes is payable semiannually in
arrears on March 1 and September 1 of each year. On December&nbsp;27, 2004, AWA called
for the redemption on January&nbsp;26, 2005 of all of the senior unsecured notes at a
redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid
interest through the redemption date. In addition, AWA irrevocably deposited the
$30.8&nbsp;million raised through the maintenance facility and flight training center
financing, together with an additional $10.5&nbsp;million from its operating cash flow,
with the trustee for the senior unsecured notes. The senior notes were
subsequently redeemed on January&nbsp;26, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(e)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In connection with the closing of the government guaranteed loan and the
related transactions, Holdings issued $104.5&nbsp;million of 7.5% convertible senior
notes due 2009, of which approximately $112.3&nbsp;million remained outstanding at
December&nbsp;31, 2004 (including $21.6&nbsp;million of interest paid through December&nbsp;31,
2004 as a deemed loan added to the initial principal thereof). Beginning January
18, 2005, these notes are convertible into shares of class B common stock, at the
option of the holders, at an initial conversion price of $12.00 per share or a
conversion ratio of approximately 83.333 shares per $1,000 principal amount of
such notes, subject to standard anti-dilution adjustments. Interest on the 7.5%
convertible senior notes is payable semiannually in arrears on June 1 and December
1 of each year. At Holdings&#146; option, the first six interest payments were payable
in the form of a deemed loan added to the principal amount of these notes. The
7.5% convertible senior notes will mature on January&nbsp;18, 2009 unless earlier
converted or redeemed. The payment of principal, premium and interest on the 7.5%
convertible senior notes is fully and unconditionally guaranteed by AWA.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Holdings may redeem some or all of the 7.5% convertible senior notes at any time
before January&nbsp;18, 2005, at a redemption price equal to $1,000 per note to be
redeemed if (A)&nbsp;the closing price of the class B common stock has exceeded 120% of
the conversion price then in effect for at least 20 trading days within a period of
30 consecutive trading days ending on the trading day before the date of the
mailing of the redemption notice, and (B)&nbsp;a shelf registration statement covering
resales of the notes and the class B common stock issuable upon conversion thereof
is effective and available for use and is expected to remain effective and
available for use for the 30&nbsp;days following the redemption date, unless
registration is no longer required. Holdings may redeem the 7.5% convertible
senior notes, in whole or in part, on or after January&nbsp;18, 2005 at the following
redemption prices (expressed as percentages of the principal amount thereof), if
redeemed during the twelve-month period commencing on January&nbsp;18 of the years set
forth below, plus, in each case, accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the date
of redemption:</TD>
</TR>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>For financial reporting purposes, AWA recorded the convertible senior notes at
their fair market value on the date of issuance. The balance at December&nbsp;31, 2004
is net of an unamortized discount of $22.2&nbsp;million.</TD>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(f)&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In July and August of 2003, AWA completed a private placement of approximately
$86.8&nbsp;million issue price of 7.25% Senior Exchangeable Notes due 2023. The notes
bear cash interest at 2.49% per year until July&nbsp;30, 2008. Thereafter, the notes
will cease bearing cash interest and begin accruing original issue discount daily
at a rate of 7.25% per year until maturity. Each note was issued at a price of
$343.61 and is exchangeable for class B common stock of Holdings at an exchange
ratio of 32.038 shares per $1,000 principal amount at maturity of the notes
(subject to adjustment in certain circumstances). This represents an equivalent
conversion price of approximately $10.73 per share. The aggregate amount due at
maturity, including accrued original issue discount from July&nbsp;31, 2008, will be
$252,695,000. The notes are unconditionally guaranteed on a senior unsecured
basis by Holdings.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Holders may exchange their notes for the shares of class B common stock of Holdings
in any fiscal quarter commencing after September&nbsp;30, 2003, if, as of the last day
of the preceding fiscal quarter, the closing sale price of the class B common stock
for at least 20 trading days in a period of 30 consecutive trading days ending on
the last trading day of such preceding fiscal quarter is more than 110% of the
accreted exchange price per share of Class&nbsp;B common stock on the last day of such
preceding fiscal quarter. If the foregoing condition is satisfied, then the notes
will be exchangeable at any time at the option of the holder through maturity. The
accreted exchange price per share as of any day will equal the issue price of a
note plus accrued original issue discount to that day divided by 32.038, subject to
any adjustments to the exchange rate through that day.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">85
</DIV>

    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On or before July&nbsp;30, 2018, a holder also may exchange its notes for shares of the
Class&nbsp;B common stock at any time after a 10 consecutive trading-day period in which
the average of the trading prices for the notes for that 10 trading-day period was
less than 103% of the average exchange value for the notes during that period.
Exchange value is equal to the product of the closing sale price for the shares of
Class&nbsp;B common stock on a given day multiplied by the then current exchange rate,
which is the number of shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock for which each note is then
exchangeable.</TD>

value of $268.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2004.
